Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Oral Choline Supplementation for Pain Management Post-Gynaecological Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: In a double-blind, randomised controlled trial, 60 women undergoing open gynaecological surgery were randomly assigned

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive 20 g of lecithin or placebo

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates oral choline supplementation with lecithin for pain management after gynaecological surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain report at rest and with movement, measured postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty participants were randomised: 30 to the intervention and 30 to the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: A small but statistically significant increase in plasma choline was observed in the intervention group (mean difference = X, 95% CI Y to Z; p = 0.XX). However, there was no significant difference in pain reports between groups (mean difference = A, 95% CI B to C; p = 0.XX).

Harms.evidence: No adverse effects were reported in either group.
